title-group.article-title: Non-linear progressive failure analysis of open-hole composite laminates under combined loading

article-meta.aff: 1Turkish Aerospace Industries (TAI), Special Programs Group, Structural Analysis Department, Kavaklıdere, Ankara, Turkey
2Department of Aerospace Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Inönü Bulvarı, Ankara, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Murat Günel, Turkish Aerospace Industries (TAI), Special Programs Group, Structural Analysis Department, P.O. Box 18, Kavaklıdere, 06692 Ankara, Turkey. Email: mgunel@tai.com.tr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article presents a finite element-based study of geometrically non-linear progressive failure analysis of open-hole composite laminates, subjected to combined in-plane and out-of-plane loading. Different ply- and constituent-based failure criteria and material property degradation schemes have been coded in Patran command language and a progressive failure analysis code is developed. Progressive failure analyses of the sample composite laminate, with an open-hole, subject to different combined loading are performed to study the effect of the geometric non-linearity on the first ply failure and progression of failure. For mode independent failure criteria, a method is proposed for the determination of separate degradation factors for fiber and matrix failures which are assumed to occur simultaneously. The results show that under combined in-plane and out-of-plane loading, depending on the load case linear analysis can significantly underestimate or overestimate the failure progression compared to the geometrically non-linear analysis even at low levels of out-of-plane loading.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The use of composite materials in primary aerospace structures is rapidly increasing. Composite laminates are the building blocks of composite aerospace sub-structures; therefore, understanding the failure characteristics of composite laminates is essential in order to exploit the full strength of composite materials in aerospace structures. Thin-walled composite aerospace sub-structures, such as skin panels of lifting surfaces or pressurized fuselage sections, are commonly exposed to combined in-plane and out-of-plane loading. Understanding the failure initiation and failure progression mechanisms of composite aerospace structures, which are subjected to common load cases encountered in flight, is very crucial to prevent premature failure and to design fault tolerant laminates. Fiber composite laminates can develop local damages such as matrix failure, fiber breakage, fiber matrix de-bonding, and delaminations which eventually cause the ultimate failure of the laminate. However before the ultimate failure, composite laminates with local damages can sustain operating loads much better than their metallic counterparts. Especially, intra-laminar local failures such as matrix cracks, fiber breakage, and fiber matrix de-bonding can be tolerated much better than inter-laminar failures such as delaminations. Progressive failure analysis of fiber-reinforced composites is a powerful method to determine the capability of composite structures to sustain loads.

Over the past three decades, many studies have been performed on the progressive failure analysis of composite laminates. In this section, some of the research done on progressive failure analysis of composite laminates is summarized. In most of these studies, mode independent and mode dependent failure criteria are used during the failure progression. Mode dependent failure criteria consist of relations which define a particular failure mode such as fiber breakage or matrix cracking, whereas mode independent failure criteria do not directly identify the failure mode or the nature of the damage. Therefore, when mode dependent failure criteria are used, direct relation between failure prediction and the failure mode facilitates the implementation of material property degradation models during the progressive failure analysis. Some key examples on the assessment of theories for predicting the failure of composite laminates include the studies of Hinton et al. [1] and Icardi et al. [2]. Literature on the progressive failure analysis of composite laminates is vast. Therefore, only some selected examples are presented in this section. Chang and Chang [3] developed a progressive failure analysis method using non-linear finite element analysis using the modified Newton–Raphson scheme. Tolson and Zabaras [4] used higher order shear deformation plate theory and performed progressive failure analysis using two-dimensional (2D) finite element analysis. Reddy and Reddy [5] compared first ply failure (FPF) loads obtained by using both linear and non-linear finite element analysis on composite plates subject to in-plane tensile loading and transverse loading. Reddy et al. [6] developed a progressive failure algorithm using the generalized layerwise plate theory of Reddy, and geometric non-linearity is taken into account in the Von Karman sense. A gradual stiffness reduction scheme was proposed to study the failure of composite laminates under tensile or bending load. Sleight [7] developed a progressive failure analysis method under geometrically non-linear deformations and implemented the method in the Comet finite element analysis code. The implementation of progressive failure analysis in commercial finite element software is often achieved through user-defined subroutines. As an example, Basu et al. [8] used Abaqus as the finite element software in the prediction of progressive failure in multidirectional composite laminated panels. Recently, Tay et al. [9] proposed element failure method for the progressive failure analysis in composites, as an alternative to the commonly used material property degradation methods, in predicting failure progression. In the element failure method, the nodal forces of finite elements are manipulated to simulate the effect of damage while leaving the material stiffness values unchanged. In their article, Tay et al. also presented a wide literature on the current strategies used in progressive failure analysis. In a recent article, Garnish and Akula [10] made a very comprehensive review of degradation models for progressive failure analysis of fiber-reinforced polymer composites.

In this article, 2D finite element-based progressive failure analysis method is used to study the FPF and progression of failure of a composite laminate with an open-hole under in-plane and out-of-plane loading and geometrically non-linear deformations. The present study is restricted to intra-laminar failures, and emphasis is given to the effect of non-linearity on the failure initiation and progression. In the progressive failure analysis of structures, which are exposed to out-of-plane loads, geometric non-linear effects become prominent when the structure is subjected to large displacement and rotation. Follower force effect, due to a change in the direction of the load as a function of displacement and rotation, is one aspect of geometric non-linearity that must also be taken into account especially when structures are subjected to out-of-plane loads resulting in large deflection. In most of the previous studies on progressive failure analysis of composites, single load case is used. Progressive failure analysis of composites under combined loads is particularly important for thin-walled aerospace structures which are usually subjected to combined in-plane and out-of-plane loads. Therefore, one of the objectives of the present study is also to investigate the significance of geometrically non-linear analysis on the progressive failure response of the composite laminate with open-hole under combined in-plane and out-of-plane loading. For this purpose, different ply- and constituent-based failure criteria and material property degradation schemes have been coded in Patran command language (PCL) [11], and finite element analyses are performed in Nastran [12]. For mode independent failure criteria, a method is proposed for the determination of separate degradation factors for fiber and matrix failures, which are assumed to occur simultaneously.

sec.title: Description of the progressive failure analysis method of composite laminates
sec.p: In the progressive failure analysis method implemented, different ply- and constituent-based failure criteria and material property degradation schemes have been coded in PCL, and a progressive failure analysis code, which employs linear and non-linear solution types of MSC Nastran, is developed.

In order to effectively allow material property degradation at the ply level, for each element in the finite element mesh, distinct composite laminate properties with distinct 2D orthotropic materials are generated for each ply via the progressive failure analysis code that is developed. Thus, stiffness reduction scheme is implemented easily for the failed ply by referencing the element property identification and material identification numbers of the ply. In the developed PCL code, distinct 2D orthotropic material is created for each ply, and then according to the pre-defined stacking sequence, distinct laminates are created for each element. Finally, for each element, distinct element properties are created by referencing the laminates which are created for each finite element in the composite laminate.

The sequence of material and property generation steps are summarized schematically in Figure 1 for a composite laminate composed of four layers. For the example shown in Figure 1, finite element model has four elements and four plies per element. After the material and property generation operations inside the PCL code, four element properties, four composite laminates, and 16 two-dimensional orthotropic materials are created. Figure 1.
Distinct ply, laminate and element property generation sequence implemented in the PCL code.

Following the model preparation, using the linear or non-linear solution types of Nastran which can be specified inside the PCL code, failure indices are calculated based on the strains or stresses at the pre-defined location within the element. In the results presented in the current article, failure indices are calculated based on the stresses at the center of shell elements, at the mid-plane of plies. Depending on the failure criterion, which is selected at the beginning, strain and stress results are processed, and failure indices are calculated for each ply in the finite element model of the composite laminate. If no failure is predicted in any ply for the particular load case, load is increased by the pre-defined load increment. If failure is predicted in a ply, then pre-selected material property degradation model is implemented and ply properties of the failed ply are degraded based on the degradation model. In case of failure of plies, PCL code starts another Nastran run at the same load level, and the load is only incremented if none of the plies in the finite element model fails according to the failure criterion used. Progressive failure analysis continues until the ultimate laminate failure or until a prescribed load level is reached.

In the current study, to visualize failure progression at the ply level, a color code scheme is also designed and implemented in the PCL code for laminates composed of eight plies. Failure progression at any load step is monitored between the FPF and ultimate failure at the ply level using the color-coded elements. Currently in the PCL code, color coding used to visualize the failure progression does not distinguish the mode of failure and the failed ply. However, one can extract the mode of failure and ply number of the failed ply from the session files easily. During the progressive failure analysis, depending on the number of failed plies, a different color is used. Thus, irrespective of the ply number of the failed ply in an element and the mode of failure, an element with one to eight failed plies is painted with different colors. The failure color coding, used for the sample applications presented in this article, is shown in Figure 2. For instance, during the failure progression, if the element is painted with red color, it means that all eight plies of the element failed according to the pre-defined failure criterion. It should be noted that although the color coding is prepared for eight-ply laminates, progressive failure analysis code is general, and composite laminates with any number of plies can be handled. Figure 2.
Color coding used for ply failures in eight-ply composite laminates.

In the present study, plane stress failure criterion of Hashin [13] and Tsai–Wu [14] failure criterion are implemented in the progressive failure analysis code. In the following, failure criteria and material property degradation methods, which are implemented in the progressive failure analysis code, are summarized. For mode independent failure criteria, a method is proposed for the determination of separate material property degradation factors for fiber and matrix failures, which are assumed to occur simultaneously. The proposed method is demonstrated on the mode independent Tsai–Wu failure criterion.

sec.title: Hashin’s failure criteria and material property degradation method used
sec.p: Plane stress failure criterion of Hashin [13] is an example of mode dependent failure criterion. Failure modes of Hashin’s failure criterion are expressed in terms of fiber and matrix failures in tension and compression, and they are given by equations (1) and (2).

Fiber failure modes: (tension: σ1 > 0, compression: σ1 < 0) (1)in tension (σ1XT)2+(τ12S)2≥1; in compression (σ1XC)2≥1 Matrix failure modes: (tension: σ2 > 0, compression: σ2 < 0) (2)in tension (σ2YT)2+(τ12S)2≥1; in compression σ2YC[(YC2S)2-1]+(σ22S)2+(τ12S)2≥1 In equations (1) and (2), “1” and “2” directions are the fiber and transverse directions, respectively. Composite material allowables in the fiber and the transverse directions are denoted by X and Y, with subscripts T and C representing tension and compression, and S denotes the in-plane shear allowable.

Material property degradation method that is used with the mode dependent failure criteria depends on the mode of failure. For the 2D lamination theory with the transverse shear deformation effects included, degraded properties for the fiber and matrix failure modes are given separately by equations (3) and (4). (3)Fiberfailures:(E1,G12,G13,ν12)degraded=R×(E1,G12,G13,ν12)previous (4)Matrixfailures:(E2,G12,G23,ν21)degraded=R×(E2,G12,G23,ν21)previous where the factor R is the degradation factor, which can be adjusted to degrade the material properties suddenly or gradually. In the present study, for sudden degradation material property degradation factor of 0.001 is used, and for gradual degradation a factor of 0.5 is used. In case of gradual degradation, plies are allowed to fail repeatedly until the degradation factor reaches 0.001, which is the factor that is used to indicate complete fiber or matrix failure in this study. It should be noted that although the plane stress form of the Hashin’s failure criterion is used, the out-of-plane shear moduli are also degraded in the fiber and the matrix failure modes, because in the finite element model individual layers are defined as 2D orthotropic material with transverse shear deformation included.

For the fiber failure case, Figure 3 shows a schematic drawing which helps in understanding the induced failures better. Figure 3.
Schematic drawing of fiber failure of a representative element in uni-directional composite.

In case of fiber failure, modulus of the composite in the fiber direction “1” is degraded because in unidirectional composites, it is assumed that fibers are the main load carrying members. The transverse load is assumed to be primarily carried by the matrix; therefore, modulus of the composite in the transverse direction “2” is not degraded. Since fiber failures cause loss of stiffness in the fiber direction but the transverse modulus is not degraded, the in-plane Poissons’s ratio (ν12) is also degraded by the same degradation factor used in degrading the modulus in the fiber direction. It is generally assumed that fiber failure also induces in-plane shear failure; therefore, in-plane shear modulus G12 is also degraded. From Figure 3, it can be deduced that for uni-directional composites, in-plane shear modulus G12 and out-of-plane shear modulus G13 are affected similarly from the fiber failure. Therefore, out-of-plane shear modulus G13 is also degraded by the same degradation factor used in degrading G12. Finally, in case of fiber failures, out-of-plane shear modulus G23 is not degraded because fiber breakage does not affect the shear modulus in the 2–3 plane as severely as it affects the shear modulus in the 1–3 plane. One further note is that for transversely isotropic materials, out-of-plane shear modulus G23 is given by E2/2(1+ν23). If one assumes isotropy in the 2–3 plane, then shear modulus G23 is directly related to transverse modulus E2 which is not degraded in case of fiber failure. Thus, from a pure mathematical point of view, it can be assumed that out-of-plane shear modulus G23 is not affected significantly by the fiber failure.
In case of matrix failure, similar arguments can be made in selecting the elastic constants given in equation (4) which are to be degraded once matrix failure is predicted by the failure criterion.

sec.title: Mode independent failure criterion and material property degradation method used
sec.p: In the current study, in order to demonstrate how the mode independent failure criterion is included in the progressive failure analysis, failure criterion proposed by Tsai–Wu [14] is used in the case studies presented. For the plane stress state, failure index of the Tsai–Wu ply failure criterion, which is implemented in the progressive failure analysis code, is calculated by equation (5). (5)F1σ1+F11σ12+F2σ2+F22σ22+F66τ122+F12σ1σ2=FI where (6)F1=1XT-1XCF11=1XTXCF2=1YT-1YCF22=1YTYCF66=1S2 and the interaction coefficient F12 is given by: (7)F12=-121XTXCYTYC In the literature, material property degradation associated with failure predicted by the Tsai–Wu failure criterion is implemented by identifying a mode of failure which is based on the stress component that contributes maximum to the failure index. For instance, if the maximum contribution to the failure index is due to σ1, then fiber failure is assumed. Similarly, if maximum contribution to failure index is due to combination of σ2 or τ12, then matrix failure is assumed. However, this method of material property degradation disregards the contribution of all stress components to the failure index and puts the blame on only one stress component in order to identify a failure mode. In the present study, material property degradation method used with the Tsai–Wu failure criterion is modified, and the material property degradation factor, which is selected in the beginning of the analysis, is manipulated to yield two separate degradation factors that are to be used with fiber and matrix failure modes which are assumed to occur simultaneously. The decision on the separate degradation factors is based on the selection of an appropriate decay function defined in terms of fiber and matrix failure indices. If the pre-selected degradation factor is R, then the requirement from the degradation factor associated with fiber failure (Rf) is that Rf should be equal to 1 when the fiber failure index is 0, and Rf should be equal to R when the fiber failure index is 1. The same logic holds for the degradation factor (Rm) associated with the matrix failure. For the intermediate values of the fiber and matrix failure indices, a decay function, which is suitable for the pre-selected degradation factor R, is selected. The choice of the decay function is arbitrary; however, it can be tuned so that results of progressive failure analysis match any available experimental failure data. To calculate separate degradation factors associated with fiber and matrix failures, failure indices corresponding to failure modes are separated as: (8)FF=F1σ1+F11σ12+F12σ1σ2(|σ1||σ1|+|σ2|) (9)MF=F2σ2+F22σ22+F66τ122+F12σ1σ2(|σ2||σ1|+|σ2|) where FF is the fiber failure index and MF is the matrix failure index, and it is assumed that the interaction term contributes to both modes of failure, in proportion to the fiber direction and transverse direction axial stresses. In the mode independent Tsai–Wu failure criterion, it is assumed that ply failure occurs when the summation of the fiber and the matrix failure indices is greater than or equal to one. In the modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion, separate degradation factors associated with the fiber and the matrix failures are calculated only after the ply failure is predicted.

For sudden degradation, it is expected that the degradation factors, associated with fiber and matrix failures, should decay fast with the failure index, and for gradual degradation, gradual decay of the degradation factors with the fiber and matrix failure indices is more reasonable. Whether sudden or gradual, for all levels of material property degradation, an exponential decay function is considered to be appropriate in calculating the separate degradation factors associated with the fiber and matrix failures. If the pre-selected degradation factor is R, then degradation factors, associated with fiber and matrix modes of failure, are proposed to be calculated by the exponential decay functions given by equation (10). (10)Rf=elnR×FF Rm=elnR×MF where Rf and Rm are the separate fiber and matrix degradation factors to be used with the fiber and matrix failure modes, which are assumed to occur simultaneously. The exponential decay functions satisfy the following conditions:
Degradation factors, associated with fiber and matrix failures, become one when the failure indices are zero. A degradation factor of one implies that no material property degradation should be done.
Degradation factors, associated with fiber and matrix failures, are equal to the pre-selected degradation factor R, when the failure indices are one.
For the intermediate values of the fiber and matrix failure indices (0–1), the multiplication of the separate degradation factors is equal to the pre-selected degradation factor R. For those material properties which are degraded in both fiber and matrix modes of failure, such as the in-plane shear modulus as shown in equations (3) and (4), since the material property undergoes successive degradation, it is reasonable to expect that Rf multiplied with Rm to be close to the initially selected degradation factor R. Following the calculation of separate fiber and matrix degradation factors, equations (3) and (4) are invoked to degrade the material properties with R being replaced by Rf in equation (3) and Rm in equation (4). Such a separation of the preselected degradation factor R is considered to reflect the failure behavior better than selecting a single mode of failure when the mode independent failure criterion, such as Tsai–Wu, is used in the progressive failure analysis. As an example of gradual degradation, if the pre-selected gradual degradation factor is 0.9 and fiber and matrix indices are 0.6 and 0.4, respectively, then based on equation (10) degradation factor associated with fiber failure mode (Rf ) is approximately 0.94 and degradation factor associated with matrix failure mode (Rm) is approximately 0.96. Thus, the preselected 10% degradation in the material properties is divided into a 6% degradation in material properties associated with the fiber failure and 4% degradation in material properties associated with the matrix failure.

If sudden degradation of material properties is selected as the method to use in the progressive failure analysis, a function which decays fast with the failure indices should be used to reflect the sudden degradation of material properties better, when the fiber and matrix failure indices take on intermediate values between 0 and 1. Exponential functions given by equation (10) decay fast when the pre-selected degradation factor (R) is a low number, implying sudden degradation. In the present study, for sudden degradation of material properties, degradation factor of 0.001 is used. Although the selection of the sudden degradation factor is arbitrary, in this study, progressive failure analysis results showed that when the material properties of the failed plies are reduced by 1000, in the next load increment the failed ply is not loaded appreciably. Therefore, subsequent degradation does not change the trend of failure progression. In the present study, exponential decay function shown in Figure 4 is used to calculate the separate degradation factors associated with fiber and matrix failures when the pre-selected sudden degradation factor is 0.001. In case of sudden degradation, complete fiber or matrix failures are assumed to occur whenever the degradation factors associated with the fiber or matrix failures become less than or equal to 0.001, or in the general case less than or equal to R. During the progressive failure analysis, after the failure is predicted in a ply, separate fiber and matrix degradation factors are calculated and elastic properties are degraded in accordance with equations (3) and (4). However, failure color coding is invoked whenever the product of the fiber or the product of the matrix degradation factors, at each step of the progressive failure analysis, become less than or equal to the pre-selected degradation factor. As a final note, it should be stated that in the present study, for the mode independent Tsai–Wu failure criterion, progressive failure analysis is performed by two different methods. In the first method, the classical approach is used and a failure mode is identified based on the relative magnitudes of the fiber and matrix failure indices, and material property degradations are done based on single mode of failure; i.e. fiber or matrix. In the second method, exponential decay functions, given by equation (10), are used to calculate two separate degradation factors that are to be used with fiber and matrix failure modes, which are assumed to occur simultaneously. Figure 4.
Exponential decay function used to determine separate degradation factors; R = 0.001.

sec.title: Description of the model and the laminate definition
sec.p:
In the present study, a rectangular composite laminate with a central open-hole is used as the model in the case studies. Figure 5 shows the geometry, boundary definition, and the shell finite element mesh of the 400 mm × 200 mm composite laminate with an open-hole of 100 mm in diameter at the center. Boundaries of the laminate are denoted as W, E, N, S, and H indicating the West, East, North, South, and the open-hole boundaries, where the boundary conditions (1: x displacement; 2: y displacement; 3: z displacement; 4: x rotation; 5: y rotation) are specified, respectively. Composite laminate is composed of eight, 0.1308-mm-thick T300/N5208 pre-preg plies. The test laminate is a balanced symmetric laminate with a stacking sequence [0/90/45/−45]s. Material properties of the ply material are: E1=132.38GPa, E2=1 0.76GPa, ν12=0.24,G12=G13=5.66GPa, G23=3.38GPa, Xt=1513.4MPa,Xc=1696MPa, Yt=44MPa, Yc=44MPa, S=86.87MPa Progressive failure analysis of the composite laminate with an open-hole is performed for four different load cases summarized in Table 1. Boundary conditions are applied along the W, E, N, and S edges, and in Table 1 numbers specified next to the edges indicate those degrees of freedom which are fixed. In the load cases studied, in-plane load is applied through nodal forces which act at each node on the east edge E, as shown in Figure 5, and uniform pressure is applied on the top surface. Since shell elements are used in the finite element model and 2D failure theories are employed in the progressive failure analysis, the effect of pressure loading only shows up in the in-plane loads generated due to the pressure induced bending of the laminate. It should be noted that in thin-walled laminates, pressure-induced bending stresses are much higher than the through the thickness normal stress, and this fact justifies the use of 2D failure theory and shell finite element model in the progressive failure analysis. For the tensile loading, symmetry boundary conditions are applied along the mid-lines between the outer boundaries and the inner boundary, as shown in Figure 5 and indicated in Table 1. In the analyses, for the combined pressure and axial loading, pressure is allowed to follow deformation but axial load is assumed to have a fix direction. Figure 5.
Laminate geometry and boundary definitions.
Table 1.
Load cases and boundary conditions.
Load cases Boundary conditions
1 T W, E: 3; W-H, E-H: 2,4; N-H, S-H: 1,5
2 P W, E, N, S: 1,2,3
3 P + T W: 1,2,3; N, S, E: 2,3
4 P + C W: 1,2,3; N, S, E: 2,3
T: tension; C: compression; P: pressure.

sec.title: Verification study
sec.p:
Besides comparisons with the hand calculations, for verification purposes, a further study is performed by comparing the results of the present study with the results of experiments performed by Chang and Chang [3] and analysis results of Sleight [7]. For this purpose, progressive failure analysis of a 20-ply laminate, which has a centrally located open-hole, is performed, and FPF and ultimate failure loads are determined and compared with the corresponding failure loads given by Chang et al. and Sleight. Figure 6 shows the tensile test specimen, which consists of T300/1034-C carbon fiber-reinforced epoxy layers with nominal ply thickness 0.1308 mm. Stacking sequence of the test specimen is [0/(±45)3/903]s, and material properties of the ply are taken from the works of Chang and Chang [3] and Sleight [7]. The results of the present study are also compared with the finite element results of the Sleight [7]; therefore, the same finite element model used by Sleight is generated and used in the failure analysis. Since the effect of geometric non-linearity is expected to be negligible in pure tensile loading, progressive failure analysis is performed by the geometrically linear analysis. Figure 6.
Tensile test specimen used in the simulations [3,7].

The comparison of load/displacement curves is shown in Figure 7. The load/displacement curve of the Sleight [7] is obtained by digitalizing the load displacement curve given in his report which does not contain the sudden load drop-off region. In the present analysis, Hashin’s failure criterion, which is also used by Sleight, is used in failure predictions. Figure 7.
Comparison of the load displacement curves of the present study and Sleight [7].

As shown in Figure 7, progressive failure analysis code developed predicts higher ultimate failure load than those predicted by Sleight. Table 2 compares the FPF and ultimate failure loads predicted in the present study, finite element results presented in the report by Sleight [7], and experimental results of Chang and Chang [3]. It is noticed that although the load displacement curves of the present analysis and Sleight are on top of each other, there is 18% difference between the first ply loads. On the other hand, ultimate failure load predicted in the present study is within 5% of the experimental result, and more close to the experimental result of Chang and Chang [3] than the ultimate load predicted by Sleight [7]. However, in the present study, ultimate load, which is predicted, is higher than the experimentally determined ultimate load of Chang. In the present study, ultimate load is taken as the load at which a very sharp drop in the constraints forces, at the free edge where the input displacement is applied during a displacement controlled virtual tensile test, is observed. Figure 7 shows the sharp drop in the load very clearly. It should be noted that during the progressive failure analysis, up to the FPF load, the degradation method does not have any effect on the results. Therefore, while comparing results of developed method with the results of Sleight [7], since same failure criterion is used in both studies, finite element codes used and stress evaluation points are considered to be the main reasons for the discrepancy in the FPF loads. Table 2.
Comparison of failure loads based on the failure criterion of Hashin.
Study First ply failure load (N) Ultimate failure load (N)
Present study (FE based) 8020 16,508
Sleight [7] (FE based) 6761 14,287
Chang [3] (experimental) Unavailable 15,671

When the progressive methodology of Sleight is examined, it is noticed that failure predictions have been made by using stresses calculated at Gauss points. If failure is detected in any Gauss point, the degradation has been performed for the material properties of the associated Gauss point. However, in the present study, the stresses are evaluated at the element centers of the layered shell elements which are used to model the tensile test specimen. Therefore, the main difference between the results of the present study and that of Sleight [7] is considered to be due to use of different failure evaluation points. For the verification study, Günel [15] has created a three-dimensional finite element model of the composite laminate using hexagonal elements and used Gauss point stresses to evaluate the failure indices at the FPF load of Sleight. Table 3 shows the Hashin failure indices calculated at the most critical element based on the stresses calculated at the element center and at the Gauss points. It is seen that although the failure index calculated based on the stresses calculated at the element center is less than 1 indicating no failure, there are four Gauss points with failure indices greater than 1 indicating failure initiation. However, since one of the aims of the article is to study the effect of geometric non-linearity on the failure initiation and progression in composite laminates, in the remaining part of the article stress recovery point is taken as the element center rather than Gauss points due to ease of extracting stresses at element center in Nastran. Table 3.
Hashin failure indices calculated based on element center and Gauss point stresses [15].
Stress recovery point Hashin failure index
Element center 0.895
Gauss point 1 0.700
Gauss point 2 0.709
Gauss point 3 1.110
Gauss point 4 1.104
Gauss point 5 0.694
Gauss point 6 0.703
Gauss point 7 1.123
Gauss point 8 1.117

Besides the discrepancy between the FPF loads, another factor contributing to the difference in the ultimate loads determined in the present study and by Sleight [7] could be due to the use of different material property degradation factors. Günel [15] has detailed explanations on the effect of the degradation factor on the difference between the ultimate failure loads of the present study and Sleight [7]. In the present study, material property degradation factor is taken as 0.001 which is higher than the degradation factor used by Sleight. Based on the failure load results presented in Table 2, it can be concluded that the effect of using different stress recovery points has less influence on the ultimate loads than it has on the FPF load, and the use of different degradation factors also has some effect on the difference between the ultimate failure loads. As it is seen in Table 2, a very low degradation factor, such as the one used by Sleight [7], underestimates the residual strength capacity of the material.

It should be noted that in progressive failure analysis, it is very hard to find an excellent match of the ultimate failure load with the experimental results. Because, in progressive failure analysis, degradation method, degradation factor and the failure theory used, all have a significant effect on the failure progression. Nevertheless, results presented in the verification section gave satisfactory feedback on the reliability of the progressive failure analysis code developed.

Finite element-based progressive failure analysis in composite laminates is known to exhibit strong mesh dependency such that often analysts are forced to calibrate input parameters of the models that are appropriate for a particular chosen mesh for a specific class of problems [16]. Efforts to reduce the mesh dependency in progressive failure analysis involve implementation of more complex material models such as energy-based material degradation models or non-local failure models [17]. It should be noted that in the current work, mesh dependency issue is not taken into consideration since in the present comparative study of geometrically linear and non-linear progressive failure analysis, both linear and non-linear analysis results are affected similarly by the mesh dependency. Therefore, in the present study, relatively coarser finite element mesh, shown in Figure 5, is used to perform analyses to avoid long solution times associated with the geometrically non-linear progressive failure analysis.

sec.title: Sample results of progressive failure analysis
sec.p: In this section, sample results of the geometrically linear and non-linear progressive failure analysis results for the composite laminate are presented for the different load cases given in Table 1. In case of geometrically non-linear analyses, large displacement-large strain implicit non-linear solution type of Nastran (SOL 600) is selected as the solver [12] in the progressive failure analysis code, and pressure is allowed to follow deformation whereas the direction of the axial force is kept fixed.

sec.title: Pure tensile loading (load case 1)
sec.p:
Progressive failure analysis of the composite laminate, under pure gradual tensile loading, is performed by the linear static (SOL 101) and implicit non-linear (SOL 600) solution types of Nastran [12] using Hashin’s failure criterion and sudden material property degradation scheme. Figure 8 shows the common FPF locations determined by the two solvers. FPF loads are determined as 14.52 kN by both the linear and the geometrically non-linear analysis, and FPF mode is identified as the matrix tension in the 90 plies (plies 2 and 7). Figure 9 gives failure progression plots obtained by the linear and non-linear analysis at an intermediate load level. In case of pure in-plane tensile loading, it is seen that although there are slight differences in the number and locations of elements with failed plies, in general geometrically non-linear analysis and linear analysis predict similar failure progression plots at the same load level, as expected. Therefore, it is concluded that for the pure tensile loading, the use of geometrically linear analysis in the progressive failure analysis of the composite laminate is justified. Figure 8.
First ply failure; load case: 1; T = 14.52 kN; failure criterion: Hashin; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis and (b) Non-linear analysis.
Figure 9.
Failure progression; load case: 1; T = 29.04 kN; failure criterion: Hashin; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis and (b) Non-linear analysis.

sec.title: Pure pressure loading (load case 2)
sec.p:
Progressive failure analysis results for pure pressure loading are obtained by using the implicit non-linear solution type of Nastran. Figure 10 shows four failure plots corresponding to load levels between the first ply pressure and the ultimate failure. For this particular example, failure theory of Hashin is used in the progressive failure analysis. In case of pure pressure loading, initial failure occurs near the edge of the open-hole along the W–E line. It is seen that although the laminate has same boundary conditions along the four edges for load case 2, for the particular laminate failure progression is not symmetric with respect to the open-hole, but failure shows somewhat anti-symmetric spread. Figure 10(c,d) shows the somewhat anti-symmetric failure progression more clearly. Anti-symmetric appearance of failure progression is attributed to the position of the ±45° layers within the laminate. For the particular laminate, −45° layers are closer to the mid-plane of the laminate; therefore, there are slight differences among the in-plane stresses in the 45° and −45° layers. Figure 10.
Failure progression; load case: 2; non-linear analysis; failure criterion: Hashin; R = 0.001. (a) P = 0.15 MPa, First ply failure, (b) P = 0.4 MPa, (c) P = 0.56 MPa and (d) P = 0.78 MPa, Ultimate failure.

For the pre-preg material used in the plies of the composite laminate, since the transverse strength (Yt) is very low, matrix tension is seen to be the dominant failure mode in most load cases. As it is shown in Figure 11, under the pressure loading, transverse stress, which contributes to the matrix tensile failure in the 45° ply (third ply) of the elements along the 45° line, is slightly higher than the transverse stress in the −45° ply (fourth ply) of the elements along the −45° line. Slight differences in the stresses are the main cause for the anti-symmetric appearance of failure progression. It should be noted that if there were only tension load on the laminate, failure would not show an anti-symmetric progression since the mid-plane symmetric laminate would not exhibit out-of-plane deflection. Figure 11.
Comparison of transverse stresses in the 45°/ − 45° plies along the diagonal lines.

Figure 12 shows the failure plots which are obtained at the same pressure loads using the Tsai–Wu failure criterion in the classical sense. In the classical application of the failure criterion proposed by Tsai–Wu, a single mode of failure is assumed to occur based on the relative magnitudes of the fiber and matrix failure indices. Therefore, there is no provision for the simultaneous failure of the fiber and the matrix. Figures 10 and 12 show that failure progressions predicted by the failure criteria proposed by Hashin and Tsai–Wu are similar. Although failure is slightly more spread when Tsai–Wu failure criterion is used, ultimate failure pressures predicted by the progressive failure analysis using the failure criteria proposed by Hashin and Tsai–Wu are approximately equal to each other. It should be noted that in the present analysis ultimate failure load is taken as the load, when all plies of elements along a line fail according to the failure criterion used. Figure 12.
Failure progression; load case: 2; non-linear analysis; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) P = 0.15 MPa, First ply failure, (b) P = 0.4 MPa, (c) P = 0.56 MPa and (d) P = 0.78 MPa, Ultimate failure.
Figure 13.
Failure progression; load case: 3; non-linear analysis; failure criterion: Hashin; R = 0.001. (a) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 1.1 kN, FPF, (b) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 31.9 kN, (c) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 49.5 kN, (d) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 59.95 kN and (e) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 64.9 kN, Ultimate failure.
Figure 14.
Failure progression; load case: 3; non-linear analysis; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 1.1 kN, FPF, (b) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 31.9 kN, (c) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 49.5 kN, and (d) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 59.95 kN, Ultimate failure.

sec.title: Gradual tensile loading under constant pressure (load case 3)
sec.p:
Progressive failure analysis of the composite laminate with an open-hole is performed under combined tensile and pressure loading by employing the Hashin and Tsai–Wu failure criteria using the sudden material property degradation scheme with a degradation factor of 0.001. In load case 3, Tsai–Wu failure criterion is first applied, first in the classical sense and then in the modified sense as described before. In the present study, during the progressive failure analysis, application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion in the modified sense is referred to as the modified Tsai–Wu failure criterion. In the gradual tensile loading under constant pressure, initially FPF is determined at pure pressure loading, which is determined as 0.12 MPa, and following the FPF, pressure is kept constant and tensile load is gradually increased until ultimate failure. Figures 13–15 show the failure progression plots between the FPF and ultimate failure for the Hashin, Tsai–Wu failure criterion applied in classical sense, and Tsai–Wu failure criterion applied in the modified sense, respectively. Figure 15.
Failure progression; load case: 3; non-linear analysis; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Modified; R = 0.001. (a) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 1.1 kN, FPF, (b) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 31.9 kN, (c) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 49.5 kN and (d) P = 0.12 MPa, T = 60.5 kN, Ultimate failure.

In Figures 13–15, the total tensile load of 1.1 kN corresponds to a nodal force of 100 N which is the incremental nodal force used in the progressive failure analysis. For the incremental tensile nodal force of 100 N, there has been no change in the FPF mode; therefore, in Figures 13–15, the first total incremental tensile load is also shown together with the FPF pressure. Modified Tsai–Wu failure criterion is applied by determining separate degradation factors, given by equation (10), associated with fiber and matrix failures which are assumed to occur simultaneously every time the failure index of the failure criterion proposed by Tsai–Wu exceeds one. However, failure color coding is implemented only in case of complete fiber or matrix failures, which are assumed to occur whenever the elastic constants associated fiber failure (E1,G12,G13,ν12) or matrix failure (E2,G12,G23,ν21) are degraded below the pre-selected sudden degradation factor R times the initial values of the elastic constants.

For the combined tension and pressure loading, Hashin, classical and modified Tsai–Wu failure criteria all predict FPF, under pure pressure loading, at the intersection of the W–E axis and the edge of the open-hole in the 0° bottom ply (ply 1) in matrix tension mode. It is noted that in load case 3, pressure loading also causes axial loading in the y-direction in the laminate. Although the axial stresses in the x-direction at the intersection of the edge of the open-hole and the N–S direction are higher than the y-direction axial stresses at the intersection of the edge of the open-hole and the W–E direction, matrix tension failure is found to be more critical due to low transverse strength of T300/N5208 pre-preg layer. Therefore, FPF occurs at the intersection of the W–E axis and the edge of the open-hole in the 0° bottom ply in matrix tension mode. However, after the FPF, as the tensile force is increased gradually, failure progresses along the N–S direction of the laminate from the edge of the hole, as expected. In Figures 13–15, ultimate failure is evident due to the failure of all plies of all elements along the N–S direction from the edge of the open-hole. A comparison of Figures 13–15 reveal that failure progression plots drawn at the intermediate load levels are very similar to each other for the three failure criteria used in the progressive failure analysis. It is observed that the use of the failure criterion proposed by Hashin in the progressive failure analysis results in the highest ultimate failure load. Modified Tsai–Wu failure criterion proposed in this study gives slightly higher ultimate failure load compared to the classical Tsai–Wu failure criterion. It should be noted that in the modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion, when failure is predicted in a ply, both fiber and matrix properties are degraded simultaneously but with degradation factors greater than the initially selected degradation factor R. Therefore, in a way modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion leads to somewhat gradual degradation in the progressive failure analysis. Since simultaneous degradation of the elastic properties associated with fiber and matrix failures is allowed, failure is more dispersed in a ply as clearly seen in Figure 15(d). Therefore, it is deemed that modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion represents the state of failure in the laminate better, compared to the classical application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion in the progressive failure analysis. However, more comparative studies have to be performed utilizing the modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion in the progressive failure analysis to substantiate its applicability in progressive failure analysis of composite laminates.

In case of combined gradual tensile loading under constant pressure, FPF loads and the spread of failure at an intermediate load level due to the linear and the geometrically non-linear analysis (SOL 600) are compared in Figures 16 and 17. Hashin’s failure criterion is used in both linear and non-linear analysis. Figure 16 shows that linear analysis predicts a FPF pressure of 0.006 MPa, which is much lower compared to the FPF pressure of 0.12 MPa predicted by the non-linear analysis. FPF is predicted in ply 1 in matrix tension mode both by linear and non-linear analysis. Figure 17 compares the failure progression at a tensile load of 38.5 kN which is applied to the laminate after the occurrence of the FPF due to pure pressure. Figure 17 shows that in case of out-of-plane loading, linear analysis highly overestimates the state of failure in the laminate. As Figure 17(a) shows, in case of linear analysis, ultimate failure of the laminate has already occurred at the tensile load of 38.5 kN, whereas in case of non-linear analysis, laminate has not reached its ultimate failure load, as seen in Figure 17(b). It is known that in case of geometric non-linearity, elongation of the fibers in the central plane of the laminate is not negligible, and the laminate stiffens due to the membrane action as it deflects laterally due to the pressure load. Thus, for the combined pressure and tensile loading, non-linear analysis predicts much lower stresses compared to linear analysis which is evident from the failure plots. It should be noted that even though the pressure is not increased after the FPF and for the pure tension case geometric non-linearity is not effective, for the combined tensile loading under constant pressure, significant differences are observed between the failure progression plots predicted by the linear and the non-linear analysis. Figure 16.
First ply failures; load case: 3; failure criterion: Hashin; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, T = 1.1 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, T = 1.1 kN.
Figure 17.
Failure progression; load case: 3; failure criterion: Hashin; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, T = 38.5 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, T = 38.5 kN.

For the combined pressure and tensile loading, Figures 18 and 19 compare the FPF and failure progression plots which are determined by the linear and the non-linear analysis using the Tsai–Wu failure criterion applied in the classical sense. In case of linear analysis, FPF is predicted in plies 1 and 8 in matrix tension mode, whereas non-linear analysis predicts FPF only in ply 1 in matrix tension mode. Failure progression plots given in Figure 19 again show that linear analysis highly overestimates the state of failure in the laminate even though the pressure is not increased after the FPF. Figure 18.
First ply failures; load case: 3; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, T = 1.1 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, T = 1.1 kN.
Figure 19.
Failure progression; load case: 3; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, T = 38.5 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, T = 38.5 kN.

sec.title: Gradual compressive loading under constant pressure (load case 4)
sec.p:
Under combined compressive and pressure loading, initial comparison of the linear and non-linear progressive failure analysis of the composite laminate is performed by employing the Tsai–Wu failure criterion in the classical sense and by using the sudden material property degradation scheme with a degradation factor of 0.001. Figure 20 compares the FPFs predicted by the linear and non-linear analysis. During the progressive failure analysis, FPF is determined for the pure pressure loading, and following the FPF, pressure is kept constant and compressive load is gradually increased and failure is progressed. In case of linear analysis, FPF is predicted in plies 1 and 8 in matrix tension mode, whereas non-linear analysis predicts FPF only in ply 1 in matrix tension mode. Figure 21 shows the comparison of the failure progression plots obtained by the linear and the non-linear analysis at an intermediate compressive load of 14.3 kN, which is applied after the FPF due to the pure pressure loading. In case of compression loading under constant pressure, as Figure 21 clearly shows, non-linear analysis predicts more widespread failure compared to the linear analysis unlike the tensile loading under constant pressure. Figure 20.
First ply failures; load case: 4; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, C = 1.1 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, C = 1.1 kN.
Figure 21.
Failure progression; load case: 4; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, C = 14.3 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, C = 14.3 kN.

Figure 22 shows the failure plots determined by the modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion at a compressive load of 11 kN at which the non-linear analysis nearly predicts ultimate failure. A comparison of Figures 21(b) and 22(b) shows that for the combined pressure and compression load case, modified application of Tsai–Wu failure criterion predicts more failure around the edge of the open-hole compared to the classical application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion in the progressive failure analysis. Figure 22.
Failure progression; load case: 4; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Modified; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, C = 11 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, C = 11 kN.

To understand the reason for higher failure progression in case of non-linear analysis in load case 4, deformation and stress contour plots of linear and non-linear analysis are compared in Figure 23–25. For the particular load level, Figures 24 and 25 show the maximum stresses among the 8 layers in the laminate. Figure 23.
Deformation plots; load case: 4; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, C = 14.3 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, C = 14.3 kN.
Figure 24.
Maximum σ1 Stress (MPa); load case: 4; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, C = 14.3 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, C = 14.3 kN.
Figure 25.
Maximum σ2 Stress (MPa); load case: 4; failure criterion: Tsai–Wu-Classical; R = 0.001. (a) Linear analysis P = 0.006 MPa, C = 14.3 kN and (b) Non-linear analysis P = 0.12 MPa, C = 14.3 kN.

Figure 23 shows that in case of combined pressure and compression loading, when the compressive load is increased, due to the secondary bending, large deformation effects become more influential and non-linear analysis predicts more realistic deformation, which is evident from the wrinkles that occur in the laminate. Figure 23 shows that wrinkles, which form in the laminate in the non-linear analysis, are absent in the deformation plot obtained by the linear analysis.

As shown in Figures 24 and 25, local bending causes higher stresses in the laminate, and the maximum fiber direction stress (σ1) and maximum transverse direction stress (σ2), as well as maximum in-plane shear stress, predicted by the non-linear analysis are significantly higher than the corresponding stresses predicted by the linear analysis. Due to the higher stresses predicted by the non-linear analysis, failure is more spread as shown in Figure 21(b) compared to the failure progression predicted by the linear analysis shown in Figure 21(a). It should be noted that in case of non-linear analysis, when the compressive load is increased after the FPF pressure is reached, the laminate also gets compressed in the width (y) direction, because in load case 4, the longer side edges of the laminate are not allowed to move in the width (y) direction. Therefore, as it is seen in Figure 21(b), all plies of the elements, near the intersection of the N–S direction and the longer side edges of the laminate, fail at the particular total compressive load of 14.3 kN which is applied after the FPF pressure. Fiber direction stress plot also confirms that the intersection of the N–S direction and the longer side edges of the laminate is the critical region because of the higher fiber direction stress, as evident in Figure 24(b). It is also noted that in case of non-linear analysis, local bending near the right edge of the laminate, where the compressive load is applied, causes higher stresses near the right edge compared to the stresses caused by the linear analysis. Therefore, failure plot, given in Figure 21(b), shows many elements with different number of failed plies near the right edge of the laminate where the in-plane load is applied. Local bending of the laminate, near the edge where the load is applied, is clearly seen in Figure 23(b) which shows that near the right edge, laminate undergoes large rotation which is absent in the linear analysis. It can be concluded that in case of combined pressure and compression loading, linear analysis underestimates the state of failure unlike the combined pressure and tensile loading.

In case of combined pressure and compression loading, local bending of the laminate, predicted by the geometrically non-linear analysis, causes higher stresses compared to the combined pressure and tension loading. The combined effect of the higher stress in the laminate and the simultaneous degradation of the elastic properties, associated with the fiber and the matrix failures, are considered to be the main reason for the higher dispersion of failure in case of modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion, compared to the classical application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion. Due to the higher stress state, the probability of predicting failure in the plies increases, and in case of failure prediction the modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion allows simultaneous degradation of the elastic properties, associated with the fiber and the matrix failures. Therefore, as shown in Figures 21(b) and 22(b), even at a lower compressive load, modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion predicts more failure compared to the classical application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion.

Failure progression plots for the combined pressure/compression and combined pressure/tension load cases are compared in Figures 26 and 27, respectively. For the combined pressure and tension case, Figure 27 gives the failure plots at the same load level as the combined pressure and compression load case. Figures 26 and 27 clearly show that due to the non-linear deformation effects which are more pronounced in the combined pressure and compression load case, laminate is more stressed and failure is more spread compared to the state of failure for the combined pressure and tension case. It should be noted that in case of combined pressure and compression, since pressure is allowed to follow deformation, follower load effect due to pressure is also more pronounced compared to the follower load effect due to pressure for the combined pressure and tension case. Figure 26 also shows that under combined pressure and compression, Tsai–Wu failure criterion, applied in the classical sense, predicts larger failure progression compared to the Hashin’s failure criterion. This example shows that the effect of using a particular failure criterion on the failure progression is also highly dependent on the load case. Depending on the load case, failure criteria proposed by Hashin and Tsai–Wu may predict similar failure progression, as in combined pressure and tension case, or may predict very different failure progression, as in combined pressure and compression case. Figure 26.
Failure progression; combined pressure and compression; non-linear analysis; R = 0.001. (a) Failure criterion: Hashin P = 0.12 MPa, C = 14.3 kN and (b) Failure criterion: Tsai-Wu-Classical P = 0.12 MPa, C = 14.3 kN.
Figure 27.
Failure progression; combined pressure and tension; non-linear analysis; R = 0.001. (a) Failure criterion: Hashin P = 0.12 MPa, T = 14.3 kN and (b) Failure criterion: Tsai-Wu-Classical P = 0.12 MPa, T = 14.3 kN.

sec.title: Effect of degradation factor on the failure progression
sec.p:
As a final case study, the effect of degradation factor on the ultimate failure load is investigated for the pure tensile loading. Since for the pure tensile loading geometric non-linearity has almost no effect, linear progressive failure analysis is performed using the failure criterion of Hashin. In case of gradual degradation, a degradation factor of 0.5 is used, and plies are allowed to fail repeatedly until the degradation factor becomes 0.001, which is the factor that is used to indicate complete fiber or matrix failure in this study. Figure 28(a,b) shows the estimated ultimate failure loads and state of failure at the ultimate failure loads for the sudden and gradual degradation of material properties, respectively. Since the ultimate failure is assumed to have occurred at the load level at which all elements, along a line which divides the laminate into two pieces, fail then from Figure 28 it is clear that in case of gradual degradation, ultimate failure load is nearly twice the ultimate failure load obtained by sudden degradation of material properties. This result is in accordance with the previous studies in the literature, such as the work of Reddy et al. [6]. Higher ultimate load in case of higher degradation factor is reasonable because in case of sudden degradation, elastic constants are reduced to small values irrespective of the damage accumulated. As stated by Reddy et al. [6], the actual size of damage in a ply is usually very small compared to the size of the finite element used. Therefore, sudden material property degradation scheme would be more meaningful to be used with the finite element models which have very fine meshes. Whereas for coarser meshes, the use of sudden degradation would cause higher failure progression, and therefore lower ultimate failure load compared to the use of gradual degradation during the progressive failure analysis. Figure 28.
Ultimate failure loads; load case: 1; linear analysis, failure criterion: Hashin. (a) R = 0.001, T = 34.1 kN and (b) R = 0.5, T = 68.2 kN.

The case study on the effect of degradation factor on the ultimate failure load showed that there is a substantial difference between the ultimate failure loads obtained by employing sudden and gradual degradation of material properties. Element size is considered to be an important factor in selecting the degradation factor. For fine mesh models, a lower degradation factor is more suitable whereas for coarser meshes, higher degradation factor is considered to be more suitable.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The effect of geometric non-linearity on the FPF and progression of failure is studied for open-hole composite laminates subjected to combined in-plane and out-of-plane loading. For this purpose, a progressive failure analysis code is developed which has the capability of performing progressive failure analysis using linear and non-linear solution types of Nastran. Progressive failure analysis is performed by employing material property degradation factor, which can be adjusted to allow any level of degradation of material properties, such as sudden or gradual, upon the prediction of failure in a ply. For mode independent failure criteria, a method is proposed for the determination of separate degradation factors associated with fiber and matrix failures which are assumed to occur simultaneously. The proposed method is demonstrated on the failure criterion proposed by Tsai–Wu. Based on the results of the progressive failure analyses, the following main conclusions are drawn.

For sudden degradation of material properties:
Under combined pressure and tensile loading, for constant pressure levels just sufficient for the FPF of the laminate and gradual tensile loading after the FPF, linear analysis highly overestimates the state of failure in the laminate.
Under combined out-of-plane and in-plane loading, linear analysis can significantly overestimate the failure progression, as shown for the combined pressure and tension case, or underestimate the failure progression, as shown for the combined pressure and compression case, compared to the geometrically non-linear analysis.
Combined pressure and compression loading causes higher failure progression compared to combined pressure and tension loading, due to the secondary bending effect of the compressive load, as well as the non-linear deformation effects which are more pronounced in the combined pressure and compression load case.
For mode independent failure criteria, application of the separate degradation factors, associated with the fiber and the matrix failures which are assumed to occur simultaneously, is demonstrated for the Tsai–Wu failure criteria. Based on the analyses performed, it is concluded that due to the simultaneous degradation of the elastic properties, associated with the fiber and the matrix failures, modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion, in general, predicts more conservative failure progression in the plies of the composite laminate compared to the failure progression predicted by the application of the Hashin and the classical application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion in the progressive failure analysis.
In case of combined pressure and compression loading, local bending of the laminate, predicted by the geometrically non-linear analysis, causes higher stresses compared to the combined pressure and tension loading. The combined effect of the higher stress in the laminate and the simultaneous degradation of the elastic properties, associated with the fiber and the matrix failures, are considered to be the main reason for the higher dispersion of failure in case of modified application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion, compared to the classical application of the Tsai–Wu failure criterion.

For gradual degradation of material properties:
Progressive failure analysis with gradual degradation of material properties results in higher ultimate loads compared to the using sudden degradation. Higher failure load, which is predicted in the present study, associated with the gradual degradation of material properties is in accordance with the results obtained by Reddy et al. [6].

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
